+  /**
+   * Constructor for sorted vector searcher.

+   * @param targetVector the vector to search for.

+

+ * Search for a particular element in the vector.
+ * @param <V> vector type.
+ */

 Review comment:
   an abstract class might be overkill in this case.  Did you consider adding a utility class with static methods (1 for unsorted and one for sorted)?  Do you expect many more implementations?  It might also be surprising to consumers that use this in there API that it doesn't work properly (and fails silenty) in some cases if the data isn't sorted.  
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

+package org.apache.arrow.algorithm.search;
+
+import org.apache.arrow.algorithm.sort.VectorValueComparator;
+import org.apache.arrow.vector.ValueVector;
+
+/**
+ * Searcher for sorted vectors.
+ * @param <V> vector type.
+ */
+public class SortedVectorSearcher<V extends ValueVector> extends VectorSearcher<V> {
+
+  /**
+   * Constructor for sorted vector searcher.
+   *
+   * @param targetVector the vector to search for.
+   * @param comparator   the criteria to determine vector data equality.
+   */
+  public SortedVectorSearcher(V targetVector, VectorValueComparator<V> comparator) {
+    super(targetVector, comparator);
+  }
+
+  @Override
+  public int search(V keyVector, int keyIndex) {
+    comparator.attachVectors(keyVector, targetVector);
+
+    // perform binary search
+    int low = 0;
+    int high = targetVector.getValueCount() - 1;
+
+    while (low <= high) {
 
 Review comment:
   Sure. It works for vectors with arbitrary length:
   
   For a single element vector, low = high = mid = 0;
   If it misses in the first iteration, the index (0) will be returned. Otherwise, it will quit the iteration, after updating low or high, and returns -1 afterward.

+package org.apache.arrow.algorithm.search;
+
+import org.apache.arrow.algorithm.sort.VectorValueComparator;
+import org.apache.arrow.vector.ValueVector;
+
+/**
+ * Search for a particular element in the vector.
+ * @param <V> vector type.
+ */
+public abstract class VectorSearcher<V extends ValueVector> {
 
 Review comment:
   For this particular PR, an abstract super class is truly a overkill, and it is a good idea to implement them as static methods. 
   
   I think more searcher implementations will be added in the future, including, for example, bucket based searcher, search tree based searcher, hash table based searcher, B-tree based searcher, etc.
   
   For me, either way is OK (add an abstract class or implement as static methods). Maybe we can add the abstract class later in the future, when we implement more search algorithms. So please give some comments.
   
   For the problem of unexpected search results in sorted searcher, do you think we should have a method to (optionally) check the vector order in O(n) time?

+import org.apache.arrow.vector.ValueVector;
+
+/**
+ * Searcher for sorted vectors.
+ * @param <V> vector type.
+ */
+public class SortedVectorSearcher<V extends ValueVector> extends VectorSearcher<V> {
+
+  /**
+   * The criteria to determine vector data equality.
+   */
+  protected final VectorValueComparator<V> comparator;
+
+  /**
+   * Constructor for sorted vector searcher.
+   *
+   * @param targetVector the vector to search for.
+   * @param comparator   the criteria to determine vector data equality.
+   */
+  public SortedVectorSearcher(V targetVector, VectorValueComparator<V> comparator) {
+    super(targetVector);
+    this.comparator = comparator;
+  }
+
+  @Override
+  public int search(V keyVector, int keyIndex) {
+    comparator.attachVectors(keyVector, targetVector);
+
+    // perform binary search
+    int low = 0;
+    int high = targetVector.getValueCount() - 1;
+
+    while (low <= high) {

 Review comment:
